args: Is this article primarily about a new action or announcement by the Trump administration/White House/Executive? Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . Man who shot Black teen ringing wrong doorbell dies before sentencing An 86-year-old White man who was awaiting sentencing for his 2023 shooting of a Black teenager who accidentally rang his doorbell in Kansas City, Missouri, has died just days after pleading guilty, according to the local prosecutor’s office, in an abrupt end to a case that has outraged civil rights activists and further spurred national conversations about racism and U.S. gun policies. Andrew Lester pleaded guilty this month to second-degree assault, a charge that carries up to seven years in prison — a significantly lesser maximum sentence than the life in prison he faced when he was charged with first-degree felony assault and armed criminal action in April 2023. On April 13 of that year, Lester shot 16-year-old honor roll student Ralph Yarl twice — including once in the head — through the glass front door of his home with a .32-caliber revolver. Yarl had rung his doorbell to pick up his 11-year-old twin brothers, who were actually at a residence a block away, at a similar-sounding address. He had never met the family of his brothers’ friends, nor had he been to their home. Yarl later recalled his confusion and disbelief when he was waiting at Lester’s door and saw a man appear with a weapon. “I hear the door open, I see this old man, and I’m assuming ‘Oh, this must be like their Grandpa,’” Yarl told ABC News in June 2023. “And then he pulls out this gun.” Yarl said he turned away from Lester, afraid but in disbelief that he would shoot. After he was shot, he fell to the ground and landed on shattered glass from the door before he ran away, screaming for help in the neighborhood. He later collapsed in another residence’s driveway. “He only said five words: ‘Don’t come here ever again,’” Yarl recounted Lester saying. Lester told police that the two did not exchange any words before the attack. The shooting became another flash point in conversations about racism and violence in the United States, with activists and rights groups again taking issue with “stand your ground” gun laws and their potential justification for the shooting of innocent Black men who are wrongly perceived as dangerous. A Missouri self-defense law states that a person can shoot if the individual “reasonably believes that such deadly force is necessary” to protect “against death, serious physical injury, or any forcible felony.” Lester had told police that he was “scared to death” of Yarl. Shortly after the incident, the Clay County prosecutor’s office noted that there was “a racial component” to the shooting. Several state lawmakers, clergy members and civil rights leaders also criticized the Kansas City Police Department for taking several days to arrest Lester, who turned himself in less than 24 hours after prosecutors issued an arrest warrant. The shooting sparked protests in Kansas City, and then-President Joe Biden called Yarl. In April 2023, Biden invited him to visit the White House. “No parent should have to worry that their kid will be shot after ringing the wrong doorbell,” Biden had said on social media. “We’ve got to keep up the fight against gun violence.” Lester’s cause of death was not released. He was scheduled to be sentenced March 7, according to Wednesday’s statement from Zachary Thompson, prosecuting attorney of Clay County. In a statement posted to Instagram, Yarl’s family said that Lester’s death “does not bring justice.” “For nearly two years, Andrew Lester never apologized. Instead, he and his attorney used every legal maneuver possible to delay accountability,” the statement reads. “Now, another Black child harmed by prejudice will never see the man who shot him face the full weight of the justice system.”
